abstract_summ: These include severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS‐CoV), followed by the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS‐CoV), and recently the SARS‐CoV‐2 coronavirus outbreak which emerged in Wuhan, China, in December 2019.From the beginning of 2002 and 2012, severe respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS‐CoV) and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS‐CoV) crossed the species barriers to infect humans, causing thousands of infections and hundreds of deaths, respectively.SARS‐CoV‐2 is a novel coronavirus that causes the acute respiratory disease—Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID‐19)—which has led to a global health crisis.Basic Protocol: SARS‐CoV‐2 plaque assay using a solid double overlay method Alternate Protocol: SARS‐CoV‐2 plaque assay using a liquid overlay and fixation‐staining methodSince the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS‐CoV‐2) infection in humans in late 2019, it has rapidly spread worldwide.Following the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS‐CoV) and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS‐CoV), another highly pathogenic coronavirus named SARS‐CoV‐2 (previously known as 2019‐nCoV) emerged in December 2019 in Wuhan, China, and rapidly spreads around the world.
title_summ: Practical Guidelines for Collection, Manipulation and Inactivation of SARS‐CoV‐2 and COVID‐19 Clinical SpecimensCOVID‐19 breakthroughs: separating fact from fictionThe emergence of a novel coronavirus (SARS‐CoV‐2) disease and their neuroinvasive propensity may affect in COVID‐19 patientsA Guide to COVID‐19: a global pandemic caused by the novel coronavirus SARS‐CoV‐2Coinfection with COVID‐19 and Coronavirus HKU1 – the critical need for repeat testing if clinically indicatedNovel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID‐19) and neurodegenerative disordersAge‐related rhesus macaque models of COVID‐19Rationale for targeting Complement in COVID‐19SARS‐CoV‐2 spike glycoprotein‐binding proteins expressed by upper respiratory tract bacteria may prevent severe viral infectionComposition and divergence of coronavirus spike proteins and host ACE2 receptors predict potential intermediate hosts of SARS‐CoV‐2The neuroinvasive potential of SARS‐CoV2 may play a role in the respiratory failure of COVID‐19 patientsSARS‐CoV‐2 coinfections: Could influenza and the common cold be beneficial?Animal models of mechanisms of SARS‐CoV‐2 infection and COVID‐19 pathologyThe Importance Of Naturally Attenuated Sars‐Cov‐2In The Fight Against Covid‐19Prevention and treatment of COVID‐19 disease by controlled modulation of innate immunityTwo Detailed Plaque Assay Protocols for the Quantification of Infectious SARS‐CoV‐2Evaluate severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 infectivity by pseudoviral particlesDoes SARS‐Cov‐2 invade the brain?A short history of COVID‐19 and other coronavirus‐related epidemicsA global treatments for coronaviruses including COVID‐19SARS‐CoV‐2 infection‐induced immune responses: friends or foes?Translational lessons from animal modelsHow did we get here?
title_abstract_phrases: These include severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS‐CoV), followed by the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS‐CoV), and recently the SARS‐CoV‐2 coronavirus outbreak which emerged in Wuhan, China, in December 2019.The neuroinvasive potential of SARS‐CoV2 may play a role in the respiratory failure of COVID‐19 patientsFollowing the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS‐CoV) and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS‐CoV), another highly pathogenic coronavirus named SARS‐CoV‐2 (previously known as 2019‐nCoV) emerged in December 2019 in Wuhan, China, and rapidly spreads around the world.Composition and divergence of coronavirus spike proteins and host ACE2 receptors predict potential intermediate hosts of SARS‐CoV‐2From the beginning of 2002 and 2012, severe respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS‐CoV) and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS‐CoV) crossed the species barriers to infect humans, causing thousands of infections and hundreds of deaths, respectively.Prevention and treatment of COVID‐19 disease by controlled modulation of innate immunityThe recent outbreak of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID‐19), triggered by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS‐CoV‐2) poses an enormous threat to global public health and economies.We use a mathematical model of viral coinfection to study SARS‐CoV‐2 coinfections, finding that SARS‐CoV‐2 replication is easily suppressed by many common respiratory viruses.
